title: More Spotify subscribers is music to investors' ears
text:
Spotify added five million subscribers in the most recent quarter to bring the total to 113m, sending shares sharply higher.

The music streaming company also posted an operating profit of €54m for the three months to September – only the second time it has been in the black since floating in April 2018.

Revenue jumped 28pc to €1.73bn (£1.35bn) as the number of paying users rose by a better than expected 31pc compared with the same period last year.

Shares rose 14pc to $137.69 in New York, reversing some of the decline suffered since August following a difficult period for Spotify.

It told investors that its shares were a third below what analysts called their true value: "Sometimes the stock price reflects the performance of the business and sometimes it doesn’t. But eventually, it always does."

Nicholas Hyett at Hargreaves Lansdown said that Spotify, "in the grand scheme of things, is expensive share for a company that doesn't make a huge amount of profit and in fact probably won't make a profit overall this year".

However, he said Spotify showed it was adding premium users - its highest-margin segment - and has showed some evidence of shifting to semi-own label music, reducing the cost of royalties to record companies.

The company also said chief financial officer Barry McCarthy would be stepping down from his post at the start of next year.

He played a key role in taking Spotify public in April 2018 in an unusual "direct listing" under which it sold no new shares.

Mr McCarthy will be replaced in January by Paul Vogel, its vice-president of financial planning and analysis, but will retain a seat on the board if shareholders give their approval.

Mr Vogel said he planned to "just to keep things going as they are".

Spotify has managed to continue adding users even as Apple and Amazon ramped up their own music streaming services. Both have tied music products to their hardware devices, such as offering services through their smart speakers and phones, and Apple Music has overtaken the Swedish company as the US market leader.

However, Spotify brushed off the threat posed by the pair, with boss Daniel Ek saying it was Spotify's "game to lose", adding: "There's a game still to be played, but at the moment we're the largest."
